Literature Review: The field of vision science has undergone significant transformations over the past six decades, with women playing an increasingly prominent role in shaping its trajectory. This literature review examines the key developments in psychophysics, color vision, hyperacuity, stereopsis, trajectory motion, and amblyopia, while highlighting the contributions of women scientists in these areas. The 1960s marked a turning point for women in science, with increased encouragement and opportunities for pursuing scientific careers. This shift coincided with advancements in vision research methodologies and theories. Hubel and Wiesel's groundbreaking work on visual cortex organization in the 1960s laid the foundation for modern understanding of visual processing (Hubel & Wiesel, 1962). Their discoveries paved the way for more detailed investigations into various aspects of vision, including those pursued by emerging women scientists. In the realm of color vision, significant progress has been made since the 1960s. The trichromatic theory of color vision, initially proposed by Young and Helmholtz, was further refined and supported by electrophysiological studies. Notably, Jacobs and colleagues conducted extensive research on color vision in both humans and non-human primates, contributing to our understanding of the evolution and mechanisms of color perception (Jacobs, 1993). Hyperacuity, the ability to make fine spatial discriminations beyond the limits set by the spacing of retinal receptors, emerged as a fascinating area of study. Westheimer's work in the 1970s and 1980s was instrumental in defining and exploring this phenomenon (Westheimer, 1975). Subsequently, researchers like Levi and Klein expanded on these findings, investigating the neural mechanisms underlying hyperacuity and its implications for visual processing (Levi & Klein, 1985). Stereopsis, or depth perception from binocular disparity, has been another area of significant advancement. The work of Julesz in the 1960s with random-dot stereograms revolutionized the study of stereoscopic vision (Julesz, 1971). Building on this foundation, researchers like Cumming and Parker have elucidated the neural correlates of stereopsis in the visual cortex (Cumming & Parker, 1997). The perception of trajectory motion has also been a focus of vision research. Studies by Nakayama and Silverman in the 1980s explored the mechanisms of motion perception and its integration with other visual cues (Nakayama & Silverman, 1988). This work has been extended by researchers like Watamaniuk, who have investigated the perception of complex motion patterns and their neural substrates (Watamaniuk et al., 1989). Amblyopia, a developmental disorder of spatial vision, has been the subject of intensive research over the past decades. The work of Hess and colleagues has been instrumental in characterizing the nature of the visual deficit in amblyopia and exploring potential treatment strategies (Hess et al., 2003). More recently, Levi and Li have made significant contributions to understanding the neural plasticity in amblyopia and developing novel approaches to its treatment (Levi & Li, 2009). Throughout these advancements, women scientists have made substantial contributions to vision research. For instance, Livingstone's work on the neural basis of visual perception has been highly influential (Livingstone & Hubel, 1988). Similarly, Braddick's research on the development of visual function in infants has provided crucial insights into the maturation of the visual system (Braddick & Atkinson, 2011). The increasing representation of women in vision science has coincided with broader societal changes and initiatives to promote gender equality in STEM fields. Organizations like the Association for Women in Science, founded in 1971, have played a crucial role in advocating for and supporting women in scientific careers (Rosser, 2012). Despite these advancements, challenges remain. Studies have shown that women in science still face barriers such as unconscious bias, work-life balance issues, and underrepresentation in leadership positions (Shen, 2013). However, the progress made over the past six decades is undeniable, with women now constituting a significant proportion of vision researchers and making fundamental contributions to the field. In conclusion, the field of vision science has seen remarkable progress since the 1960s, with significant advancements in our understanding of color vision, hyperacuity, stereopsis, trajectory motion, and amblyopia. Throughout this period, women scientists have increasingly contributed to these developments, benefiting from improved opportunities and support. While challenges persist, the trajectory of women's participation and success in vision science continues to be positive, promising further advancements and discoveries in the years to come.
